body: For 3D, since it is solid harmonic we need to choose a value for L (L=2 ?). For the batch size I suggest 32x128x128x128. Is to ok ? Do we need also CPU time ?
it's ok, what are the other param? yes, GPU+CPU time

Ok. Will do 1D. Something like `128x1x262144` with `J = 10` and `Q = 8` would be reasonable, I think.

Where do we dump the results? Here?

Could you add the files in example? and add in the doc PR the results:
https://github.com/eickenberg/scattering_transform/pull/44

Is there a chance to do a generic script for testing this, so that we use the same for 1-2-3d?

Thanks,
for 3D other params are J (typically 2 or 3) and the integral powers (usually we take 1 and 2)
@louity just pick anything that sounds ok for you
OK J=2, L=2, int_powers=(1., 2.)
I'll do the 2d https://github.com/eickenberg/scattering_transform/pull/74 here

Ok, so for 1D, we're in pretty bad shape. For size `64x1x262144` with `J = 10`, `Q = 8` I have

scatnet: 6.43 s
kymatio_cpu: 18.8 s
kymatio_gpu: 12.7 s

The MATLAB/scatnet numbers vary a bit depending on what settings I use (you can't get exactly the same thing since the filterbanks are different), but it's on the order of 4-6 seconds.

Ok très bien, i'll come on this. It's ok if the 1D is very slow with the "torch" backend. We need to prepare a "skcuda" backend. I doubt it's torch FFT whiwh makes it so slow.. more like the "concat" performed a bit everywhere..

Ok, but still, the fact that the CPU version is about 3x slower suggests that there are some underlying issues in the computation.

If you can provide me some rough guidelines, I can start on the "skcuda" backend.

We need to avoid:
- concat : https://github.com/eickenberg/scattering_transform/blob/master/scattering/scattering1d/utils.py#L220-L225
- https://github.com/eickenberg/scattering_transform/blob/master/scattering/scattering1d/scattering1d.py#L559 o.O ? is this a complex dot wise multiplication?
- subsample with mean() done this way is slow.

Basically, it's any low level manipulations tensor which can be potentially inefficient that must be avoided... in the 2D backend, what I did is to make sure that *any* low level operation is performed via the "backend", even the dotwise mutliplication, in order to time them..
Ok. This is for optimizing the torch backend? I imagine implementing an skcuda backend is a whole different ball of wax?

Argh, yeah so the thing is that pytorch makes all these extra operations so easy, because you don't need to think about it much.
Some things are fixable by preallocating, but sometimes that goes against the whole pytorch autograd stuff.
In my 3D code basically all arrays were preallocated (don't know how much difference it actually makes though).

Maybe we can aim at a future `fast` backend that does everything as fast as possible even if maybe non-differentiable.

In the mean time, it's probably possible to at least speed up scattering 1D to matlab speed :)

This might help: https://github.com/rkern/line_profiler#id5

If it works, use it to find the commands that take the most time and focus on reducing the time they take (meaning if you double the speed of something that takes 5% of the time, then you have a 2.5% speedup, which is probably not worth it)

Ok. Thank you for these tips! Sounds like there's some low-hanging fruit here to pick off. Will take a look at this tomorrow.

That being said, there was quite a lot of optimization that went into the MATLAB code, so it may take some work to get it to the same performance.

So, w.r.t. my 2D matlab code i had a speed up of order 2 of magnitude. All the trick is to encapsulate the code appropriately and any of the : modulus/subssamplefourier/unpad/pad/fft/cdgmm routines should be carefully optimized. Memory allocation is not a problem anymore since torch 0.2, it's mainly concat and things like that that need a lot unecessary copy

for consistancy, I changed my batch size and parameters to the one we report on table 1 of https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01837587/document

```
==> Testing Float32 with Skcuda backend, on GPU, forward
Elapsed time: 10.76 [s / 10 evals], avg: 1.08 (s/batch)
```

```
==> Testing Float32 with Torch backend, on GPU, forward
Elapsed time: 43.84 [s / 10 evals], avg: 4.38 (s/batch)
```

redoing the exp with pyscatwave (exact same procedure), it gives 1.58s/batch

It is almost 33% gain w.r.t. pyscatwave, and i think this is thanks to the pytorch FFT.
There is a memory gain in skcuda w.r.t. torch of 500MB over about 3GB and ... well torch backend iss slower, significantly ; but backward can be activated.

CPU is still running lol 🐶  (with nproc=48 on the cluster and nobody using it, whereas i was running the gpu exp in parallel of it lul) ; and MATLAB on this one just didn't run..
EDIT:

```
==> Testing Float32 with PyTorch and Torch backend, on CPU, forward
Elapsed time: 1057.31 [s / 10 evals], avg: 105.73
```

https://github.com/edouardoyallon/scattering_transform/blob/general_doc/doc/source/userguide.rst 

please report ur definitive values here
I'll close the issue when the 1D script will be oline!
Ok. On it.
Fixed by https://github.com/eickenberg/scattering_transform/pull/93
